Diet & Body Re-composition

Initial Body Fat and Body Composition Changes

General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets
Read the above articles, and decide whether you need to bulk (add muscle), cut (lose fat), or maintain.

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69585535

Working for myself has been infinitely better than any other job I ever held. In fact nowadays most of my work stress and headaches come from the other firms I collaborate with. Since I'm a one-man business and relatively young, they always assume they can take a leadership role and treat me like one of their peons.

Get the trade job, learn the work, get good, put in your time. But don't use the whole year, don't use all of your savings if you can help it. Get started right away or you'll be tempted to "just relax for a few days or a week" and find that six months have flown by. Instead, schedule a couple of real breaks (three days, three or four times a year) when you do not make any other family or work commitments. Use those. After you've put in your time at the trade, reevaluate and think about striking out on your own.

27 y/o living in Brooklyn. Making 240k as a software engineer (maybe less - I haven't checked the stock in a while). Haven't posted on here in at least 7 years - I'm procrastinating writing self-evaluation for my performance review (due Monday night but I want to leave my weekend free).

I got together with some friends for the week before Christmas and we all did some life planning. I wanted us to all imagine where we wanted to be in our lives in 2027 (with our careers, families, friends, hobbies, physical/mental health, etc.) and what we were going to do in 2023 to move us towards at least a couple of those goals.

I'm currently a secular Jew, but years of speaking with an Orthodox Christian have convinced me to take religion seriously, so I've been trying my best to understand how to get as close to taking a "leap of faith" as possible (I started off on /his/ tonight). It seems like religion is going to give me 1) a definition of a good life 2) a schedule by which to adhere to it 3) a community of other people who are all dedicated to pursuing it. While I understand that's not the case everywhere, it's at least better than the atheists who can only rely on paid therapists. I also understand that I'm framing religion in purely humanist terms rather than as a metaphysical framework for connecting with the divine, but you know...one step at a time

I set up time to speak with spiritual leaders in my neighborhood (that was the first step in my "2023 plan"). I think once I figure out my faith, then I can start looking for a wife in the faith (I understand that I might be greatly limiting the number of women I can pursue, but most of the women in NYC aren't worth pursuing anyway right?) and then I can devote myself to a job that inspires me.

But of course, the whole time I'm going to be powerlifting! I'm still grateful to /fit/ for inspiring me over a decade ago to get into it. With all the ups and downs in my life, the weights have always been my solace

>>69592918
This, it's a tradeoff. A minor arch can be more or less universally recommended, since for the vast majority of people it's worth it just for the fact it puts your shoulders in a more comfortable position as compared to a totally flat back with pronated scapulae. Anything past that and you're trading range of motion for force output. Either can be valid strategies even if all you care about is hypertrophy - for example, you could bench press with a more aggressive arch for the higher stimulus and also do very deep dips or DB press in order to work on the end ranges of motion you're missing out on with a barbell

There are and have always been people who are married to the science or the art of whatever activity they find most engaging to them. For one it could be gardening - they feel a connection towards soil pH, compost nitrogen, and permaculture, for another it can be woodworking, and they can lose themselves in the infinite ways they can move or cut the grain into a mortise, flapjoint, carving of a bird or bowl.

Loving the action of doing something leads to long term fulfillment rather than just the product of that process. Approach love similarly, find a way to love the action of giving/receiving love rather than fixating on the idea of an extant relationship; if you aren't in the place to do that yet then you don't need it.

posts.com:
To the guy who didn't get an answer in the last thread >>69560168 hopefully you see this. Sorry I missed you bro

What you want to do is treat your stretches like reps of an exercise. Go into a stretch, hold it for 3-5 seconds, and release. While you're doing this you want to relax your hands and face and breath deeply enough that it expands not just your chest and belly but also your low back and pelvic floor a little. It's best done as 3x10 for all stretches. I learned this method from a retired polish Olympic weight lifter. I've never seen someone so flexible and using this technique made me so much more flexible too. Way better than yoga and static stretching has ever done for me

Get some dumbbells that would normally be slightly too heavy for you to do for a skull crusher with, press them up like a dumbbell bench, then lower them like you normally would as a skull crusher but over 5 or so seconds. Repeat. 3x8ish

>>69582401
>85% working weight
Not important for a bodybuilding program. Strength athletes have to use percentages session to session because they have to manipulate weight to make skill gains while also making strength gains. Your goal is to get within a hairs distance of failure by the end of your set and have it land somewhere between 8-15 (some lifts more, some less) reps. For order I'd swap the OHP and BBR and replace the hammer curl with a tricep exercise
>>69582690
Most noobs have a really hard time judging where failure is. Genuine failure on a lift will have you go from 12 reps on one set to 4 on the next. If you're already doing that then you need to save it for the last set only. If you can judge what real failure feels like you want to stop 1 or 2 reps short of that for most sets

Bulking is going to 100% be necessary for you. Lean bulk though so you don't get chubby. 0.8g/pound of bodyweight in protein, 0.35g/pound of bodyweight in fat minimum, and fill out the rest of your calories however you like. Take how SS treats legs, add calf raises, but disregard the upper body portion of that program. Here's your checklist for the upper body part of the program
>2 Horizontal Presses (includes incline work)
>2 Horizontal Pulls
>1 Vertical Push
>1-2 Vertical Pulls
>2 Curls
>2 Tricep Lifts (obligatory long head work)
>1 Lateral Raises
>1 Rear Delt Lift
The last 4 will be in giantsets and supersets usually to save time and because they won't interfere with each other's performance. Don't go below 8 reps on anything upper body related and bias high reps on the isolations. For the lateral and rear delt work push them to failure and way beyond. They can take it and thrive with that type of punishment

>>69588995
Great bodies have been built on a base of dips and chinups. You can adjust your form to bias the biceps with chinups easily but the shoulder mobility to make the dips tricep dominant isn't good for most people. Adding in the one legged squats covers almost all your bases now. After that what you need for a complete program is to work your traps and shoulders (handstand pushups), a horizontal pull (ring rows are great here), a hamstring exercise (nordic curls), and a triceps based press (lots of good pushup options). 6 exercises and the only muscles you've missed are the neck and calves which can also be easily worked with calisthenics if you want to
>>69589141
1 gram of the protein you're thinking of. The rest is collagen. Great for your skin, hair, nails, and joints, but unusable for your muscles
>>69589185
Neither are good or bad. It's dependent on the exercise or movement you're training and the structure of your shoulder joint. Picrel is one example. A type III acromion would get shoulder injuries from strict overhead pressing and would benefit from leaning back heavily (a well known sin in OHP training), but a type I could press overhead from any position, even vertical and far behind the head with no issues. When I slightly internally rotate my shoulders for lateral raises because of my structure I get better activation and less shoulder strain, while other people benefit from external rotation and would get the best results from something like a lu raise, whereas that lift has injured me in the past. Don't listen to blanket statements about something being good or bad in lifting.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69577249
based

I quit smoking for good in May 2020 at the age of 25 after relapsing off and on over the course of 7 years. Would stay clean for a few months at a time before saying "fuck it" at an opportune moment and buying another pack to start the next cycle.

Replacing smoking w/ exercise is the best way I've found to go about doing it. Smoking is a cope mechanism, has to be replaced by something else - may as well be exercise.

Once past the first week w/o smoking, the irritability and loss of focus is mostly gone. Past the first month, your brain still has subconscious behavioral patterns to iron out, but the physical effects of nicotine withdrawal are gone. Then after a year, given your age, your heart/lungs should be nearly fully recovered.

The trickiest part isn't to stop smoking, it's to stay stopped. Its a readily available coping mechanism, with a latency between an impulse to smoke and the actual act of doing of only a few minutes. 24/7 stores everywhere stacked full of em just waiting to make a dollar on you cracking.

I have had many times over the past 2.5 years where I've considered smoking again, for any myriad of reasons. The only thing stopping me from doing it is telling myself "no", and reminding myself of why I quit in the first place. Having been in the grips of addiction, it is all too easy to slip back whether through an act of frustration, despair, complacency... you cannot un-eat the fruit of knowledge.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69578463
This is the hardest part of addiction and you don't realize it until you really put an effort into quitting for good (for if you never tried quitting, there's always the possibility that "maybe one day I will quit"...) - whether you like it or not, whether you let it control you or you fight back, its going to be with you for the rest of your life. To win the war you must win the battles, and to win the battles you must have the mind of a warrior... and the easiest way to have the mind of a warrior, is to have the body of a warrior.

Godspeed and great gains unto you, anon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69589248
What the autists never realize is that 180spm is a race cadence, not a easy run/training cadence. Furthermore, cadence during a race isn't usually consistent.

So for me (183cm), when I'm doing a normal training run I'm around 140-160spm, depending on pace, pretty steady unless I'm doing stride sets or something.
When I'm running in a marathon, I'll average 165-170 for the first few km and for the last 5km or so I'll average around 180spm.

That said, most casual runners' cadence is far too low and they try to gain speed by over-striding, which is a major cause of injury. If they shorten their stride and increase their cadence, they will be faster and healthier in the long run.

tldr; you should train to run at high cadence so you can do it during a race but you should not train to run at only high cadences

Currently 18 days in. Doesn't seem like much but this time is different.

Porn has been a compulsion in me for years since I was a teen. It drove me to endless degeneracy, disgusting fetishes, cheating, and ruining my relationships and outlook on life by seeing others as conduits for my lust. Choosing to truly leave it behind was a process of months. I started experimenting with psychedelics, which led me to therapy, facing my inner conflict and the damage that was done to me when I was ostracized as a young lad for being "weird" - a mentally ill loner kid like many of us here, for which I sought comfort in escapism. I've been exercising and trying to quit porn for years in many different ways but could never stick to it. I always came crawling back until I figured out WHY I was crawling back. Because it was a dopamine spike and a coping mechanism for feeling unwanted.

I had to be humbled by a DMT trip, broke down and told the truth to my gf, and now I keep working on myself through forgiveness and gratitude. Now sex and dates with my gf are more passionate, more amazing, I appreciate her beauty more every day. I have more confidence in myself, I started going to the gym again and can focus more on my workouts, I can actually look girls in the eye without instinctively looking away for fear they'll think I'm disgusting, one or two actually started talking to me. Can you believe that? Today I even got a mire.

I still see pornographic images sometimes since I post on /drugfeel/ and /tg/ but I no longer seek them, collect them, or masturbate to them, which has been greatly liberating. Eventually I seek to cleanse myself fully but for the first time in my life, I know I can do this. Fuck the porn jew.

Many pharmaceuticals we have today were designed to mimic or be outright synthetic versions of plant alkaloids. Ephedra Sinica contains the alkaloids ephedrine and pseudoephedrine which we now use as bronchodilators and sinus decongestants respectively (and pre-workouts in the case of this board). The Chinese have been using ephedra Sinica as medicine for about 5000 years. Aspirin, caffeine, morphine, metformin, penicillin, some cancer drugs, and many others were derived from natural sources. Synthesis in a lab does give us better control, but saying that something is useless because it has a natural origin is as ridiculous as the people who believe in the all-natural meaning good for you rubbish. It's just another presentation of the naturalistic fallacy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nothing wrong with carbs.
What's wrong is that your average meal is 80% refined carbs.
Modern humans are like 50000 years old, the agricultural revolution was like 10000-12000 years ago.
If you were to find yourself 25000 years ago in some European or North American forest, you don't have many readily-available carbs anywhere. Most often you'd find some wild onions, tubers, berries. You didn't have pure sugar back then, modern fruit are all selectively bred, same goes for carb-rich vegetables such as potatoes. Most of your calories came from hunting wild game (protein+fat), cooking it allowed us to make it more nutritious. You had to move around a lot to track game (cardio).
Not to mention winter - good luck finding carbs then.
Humans evolved on a high fat, medium protein and low carb diet due to refined sugars/oils not being available.
There's a reason why grains are considered peasant food, don't forget that.
Also, a lot of modern-age diseases are associated with high sugar intake, including cavities and misaligned teeth.

A healthy hearth is pretty much the definition of being fit. Exercise, diet and good sleep will help. On the exercise part, you should combine intesive workouts (HIIT) and extensive workouts (I suggest brisk walking as it has almost no injury potential). HIIT (15-30 minutes) 2 times a week and extensive workout (60 minute walk) 2 times a week is more than enough. On the diet part: simply don’t overeat, not to much fat (except for good fats found in nuts and fish) and limit your intake of meat (you don’t need to go vegan, but too much meat is bad for you). The sleep part is pretty much self explanatory. Avoid coffee and alcohol as much as you can. That’s about it.

A wide variety of foods is good

Meat + Vegetables + Carbs + Dairy + Water is typically a balanced meal, you can add fruits as well, but you can get by with less

What is also important is the total calories. I have oats and whey typically for breakfast after lifting, so the protein absorbs quickly.

You can live on rice and beans, but you really need extra nutrients like from mixed vegetables or tomatoes or potatoes or meat or dairy or just other whole ingredients

The main difference between traditional food and factory-produced food is processing.

If the raw ingredients have been processed into a salable produce, cost and sometimes chemicals are added. The best ingredients you can get are from local farmers markets or grown on your own property.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
WAGMI edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>>69574433
I was in your shoes. About a year ago I was 457. Yes, 457 pounds. I am 6' 2" tall. Since then I started intermittent fasting and a Carnivore Diet.

My eating window is 11 am till 6 pm. I only eat eggs, steak, fish, chicken, turkey, hamburger. No buns, no fries, no potato chips, no cookies, no cake, no soft drink, NO CARBS. Stay away from Fast Food.

If you can stomach dairy some cheese or milk is ok but you are better off skipping that as well.

NO ICE CREAM.

I went from 457 to 354 this morning. I am still a big fat pig but I am losing the weight and the best part is eating this diet I don't feel hungry.

The combination of diet and fasting can really help. One other thing I strongly recommend is getting a Continuous Glucose Monitor. This can tell you what your blood glucose is. This is vital to psychologically rejecting the food you used to crave because you can see what it does to your blood sugar.

Good luck anon.

posts.com:
I am mid-way through my cut. Started as around 100kg chubby (2m tall though). I was drinking coke nearly every day, ate crisps often, and hamburger meat (the cheapest one made from chicken skin etc.).
Now I am 90kg or less (I am gonna weight myself tommorow, since I do it once a week not to stress over small day to day variation). I gradually cut coke from my diet and moved to sugar + tea made at home then switched to water and sugarless tea (I started to actually enjoy it after a week or two without adding sugar to anything). I cut carbs a lot - no bread, less pasta if possible, no snacks, potatoes stayed though (baked ones are delicious af). I switched to non-processed foods, like chicken, fruits, veggies, cottage cheese etc. (I am aiming to get 1g of protein per kg of my weight, don't care about other macros). Recently I started to go on a walks (around 12km in 2h) everyday, yesterday I added on top of that swimming pool visit. I also fast every friday (with coffee and water). I floor press barbell every 3rd day 3x15 (last one was 30kg) to build some chest muscles to combat manboobs, I think I will also add some core exercises (pulling up knees while hanging on bar) because my current goal is to twinkmaxx and then as my age progresses (23 atm) I will build more muscle to be more manly (around the time my beard will start looking good).
I am losing around 1kg a week, although I think this week it'll be more, my goal is 80kg, I might go lover if I am not satisfied, or try hard to stay 80 and just reduce bf% - will decide when I get there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69587601
I've lost and gained weight, and every single time I fell off in a major way came from feeling miserable about the way my lifestyle ended up feeling on the days where I was feeling fragile. Resent it long enough, and one tragedy (and it the severity scales with your resentment) to throw you completely into despair, and then you'll need to recoup your determination again.

Depending on how big you are, sometimes you can recoup quickly enough that you can get back on the horse without ruining the bigger progress... But this is where you need to be your own trainer, because no one will know what you're capable of except you, and it takes a lot to even push yourself to know what you're *really* capable of.

Muscle measurements (meaning if you're at the same bodyweight and your arm increased in size by an inch you've gained muscle), strength increases over time that are correlated with muscle gains (firstly, strength gain at a similar bodyweight, or same strength/small strength loss at a lighter bodyweight, or a very large strength gain at a greater bodyweight; secondly, no extreme changes in neurological adaptation or technical ability, meaning that if you peaked your squat, you did get stronger but you didn't actually gain muscle as this is simply a result of neurological adaptation not increased muscle mass), and finally, the mirror.

i had a hip labrum tear repaired last june, it took about 3 months to get into exercises that resembled lifting. I still get pain when doing squats or anything that requires full range of motion. I also got nerve damage to my pudendal nerve that made my dick numb and it's still numb in some places 7 months later. My entire leg is also still swollen and I'm having hip snapping.

Orthopedic surgery isn't the best. Your recovery will likely be much longer than they say. up to 60% of all surgery patients have chronic nerve pain after surgery. You may be one of the lucky ones and bounce back quickly, but the odds are actually much higher than your surgeon would admit to that you may have some chronic issues still after surgery. The surgeon that did my repair is one of the best in the world and I still have issues.

posts.com: For motivation I'm posting my story thus far again. I was fat as fuck and a depressed sack of shit going into 2021. My long term gf left me, I was jobless and aimlessly spinning my wheels in life. I managed to find work again and spent the next year getting fat, unhappy and drawing away from anyone in my life. I was drinking very heavily. Last summer I weighed myself for the first time in almost 2 years. I was 310 pounds, had to buy bigger clothes and was spending every night alone, miserable and eating myself to death for brief feelings of comfort. At my lowest I had set a handgun on the table loaded and stared at it for an hour wondering if it was all even worth it. Then a friend reached out to me and offered to be my gym partner as he had been going for a couple years at that point. I accepted and bought a membership that day. Since then I've been consistent and I've passed 1/2/3/4, stopped drinking and have lost 30 pounds. I have much more to go but my progress has put my life back on track. I found my friends again and now we're closer than ever. I've never had an interest in running but now it feels like I'm free from the prison i turned my body into. I run for a mile and a half a day now. And every day i get better. I used to not even be able to walk far without sweating like a pig. Now at the end of my cardio sessions, I find freedom in sprinting to the finish. The shackles I hung on myself feel like they have been left behind. I now am starting a business with my friends and my old clothes fit again. I'm in better shape than I have been in years. My whole life is turning around thanks to heavy lifting. Now at 280 pounds I can for the first time do 3 pull-ups in a row. I'm well on my way to reversing so much h of the damage I've done to myself. The biggest help you can ever have is yourself. WAGMI

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69584265
For starters if that's you don't deadlift in those fucking shoes. Either get nice flat ones or go barefoot. For deads you gotta practice the hip hinge. Bracing your core is vital as well, gotta take a good deep breath and then do as if you're trying to exhale through your mouth (both nose and it should be closed though, don't let the air out). Then you drive through with your legs as if you're trying to push the floor away from you, keeping your back straight - the knees will naturally move backwards and as you lift the bar above them your hips should thrust forward and that's that. A description like that helped me get my deads good and proper and I never had issues, as a 17yo noob at the time with this I went from a 70kg dead to 175kg 3x5. Search around on Google as well as YT, I find T-Nation has some good text descriptions on how to perform exercises properly. Note that when you're lifting very heavy you will 9/10 times not have perfect form, it just needs to be good enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69551455
lot of conflicting information with no real straightforward answer. Anecdotally ime the guys who have issues with it are doing two things
>running absurdly high GH doses for a long period
I'm talking 10iu+/day without ever taking breaks, or only adjusting that dose down by 2iu as a "break"
>not monitoring insulin sensitivity on GH by supplementing berberine/metformin
no solid research on this afaik, but again anecdotally there seems to be a high correlation between guys who are not countering the potential insulin related issues GH brings with it and having these negative effects

4-6iu isn't a giga dose, but is high enough I would personally recommend breaks. I take a break from GH every time I cruise, about 12 weeks total out of the year. I always supplement with metformin and/or berberine while on GH.

Oh, last point, if you have side effects from the GH itself (numbness, lots of water retention, aches) back down by 1-2iu until you no longer do. For most this is the 6-10iu range, personally I can run 7iu without issues, 8 gives me problems.

so, as with anything posted about gear online, there's half truths to it. Yeah, some pros are running fucking retarded cycles, many of them because their coach tells them it just werks(tm) and they don't question a thing or take their health into consideration
see >>69550280
but i do think the doses listed here are overblown. 3-5g not so much, 5g+ is not going to give you more than a handful of years on a competitive stage unless you tolerate gear exceptionally well or are not considering your health outside of your next competition window

and, again, as with anything gear related online, there are outliers on the other end of the spectrum too. Some guys can run 1g-1.5g and do insanely well, because they've figured out what works for them and what they tolerate. the portions about stim abuse and what kills guys are largely true, but you need to consider the LONG TERM side effects of AAS as well. stims, diuretics, etc. are going to kill guys short term, but many still suffer from retarded cycles year after year

insulin/gh portion is also correct, and so is this anon >>69552591
the caveat regarding genetics, though, is that there does still exist genetic variation in response to gear. The guys on 5g+ wouldn't be running that if they could do as well as the guys on 1.5g are with the same amount of gear. But it's not all tied to genetics, it's simply a compensatory factor to take into consideration.

>>69557845
>>high test
>>19nor
>>dht derivative
I disagree, 19nors and DHT derivatives aren't for everyone. 19nors are another variable you have to worry about (prolactin) and are the high risk:high reward steroids, even the 'mild' nandrolone (deca/npp) has been linked to long-term heart problems. DHT derivatives are fine for some people but bad for others, they're the ones that are infamous for destroying hairlines in some people.

I think the first three cycles should follow a flow chart:

Cycle #1: Everybody starts at 500mg test
>How badly did you aromatize?
Not bad => 500 or more test base in your next cycle
Kinda bad => 400 or less test base in your next cycle [unless you are running Primo or EQ, which have mild AI properties]
>Did you experience any hair loss and/or do you care?
No hair loss/I don't care about being bald => add in a DHT derivative in cycle #2
I'm paranoid about my hair => DHT derivatives are off the table, throw in EQ for cycle #2

Cycle #2: Test + DHT (Mast or Primo) OR Test + EQ, dosage varies due to how well you handled cycle #1

For next cycle decide whether you want mass at any cost or if you don't want to mess with 19nors
I want to be huge => Throw in some deca/npp
I don't want to leave humanity behind => rerun cycle #2 but with higher dosages and/or an oral

Cycle #3: Test + (Primo/EQ) + (Deca/NPP) OR Test + (Primo/EQ) [+ oral]

Not inherently for the 19nor, I am not familiar with the DHT/Prolactin interaction because I myself never have prolactin related issues. I would assume it offers some benefit but that is a total guess. I personally run a DHT derivative because it allows me to push test a little higher once added in, without needing a true AI. I can go from about 1g test/wk without AI with no mast in a stack, and after adding mast can bump that to 1.2-1.4 without issue. Trying to run 1.2-1.4 test otherwise gives me god awful side effects. As for ratios, I don't think ratios are as important as guys make them out to be. Actually let me rephrase that, they are important, but the individual variability is so wild with ratios that some guys might be fine running low test crazy high 19nor, others might have the worst time of their life. My advice for adding anything is always to start reasonably low (for yoru stack, lets say 200 or 300mg) and work up.

If it’s shipped domestic to domestic USPS, they, or the police can’t open your mail without a warrant. They don’t have drug dogs for steroids and sources tape up their boxes well and usually air seal the gear.

The worst that could happen is that it accidentally gets delivered to your neighbors house and they open it. If they called the police about it I’m not sure what would happen since it’s illegal to open someone else’s mail. And I’m pretty sure illegally obtained evidence can’t be used in court to get a warrant but I could be wrong.

I’ve spent way too much time thinking about this because I used to have a neighbor with dementia that opened my mail twice and gave it to me after, thankfully she never opened my gear.

Oh yeah and some people say a P.O. box is more sketchy because anyone could mail anything to your house, they just need your name and home address which isn’t hard to find. But not with a P.O. box because you have to give someone your P.O. box address to get something mailed there. Something mailed to your P.O. box implies you most likely gave the P.O. box address to someone to get gear mailed there. Although some people claim to use P.O. boxes with no issues, some sources will not ship to P.O. boxes.

>Post tricks to fall asleep?
1. Put on podcast or music.
2. Flex and relax all muscles one by one.
3. Ignore everything (including music and thoughts) and let your mind wander.
The last step is really fucking important. Focusing on anything will keep you awake. Never let your attention sit on one thing. Ignore the idiot fucks that tell you to focus on breathing, sheep counting, or anything that requires attention. You want the opposite. You want to unfocus. You want to blur. It may take a long time to get this part right at first.

>>69592112
They don't really have anything to do with posture unless you are already fucking up your posture. You're just not doing enough of them to work against normal scapular depression in any meaningful way. Athletes who do repetitive motions like throwing or serving are much more likely to develop scapular dyskinesis than someone doing shrugs. The only time shrugs could be harmful is if you're already doing exercises that work the traps like shoulder/military press and then add shrugs. Too much overhead and raising motion will lead to things like poor posture, rotator cuff injury, etc...

I made 0.05% minoxidil/finasteride mix that I started applying topically in August, but continued to see loss trying to get proper coverage. Starting last week after seeing incredibly positive results I started taking it orally, less than 0.1ml per day for a microdose of fin/min. Will report back routinely in /fit/ hair threads.

>b-b-b-but oral min is bad
The studies that showed adverse heart health effects were daily doses of 40mg+. 5mg or less, especially taken as two 2.5mg doses, are incredibly well tolerated.

>bubbubtububut muh liquid minox dangerous
Yeah if you drink too much. The most dangerous substance in it is the minox itself. The other ingredients are water and alcohol.

>bubtbutbubt--tbut-tbut muh that's not enough fin!
Actually this microdosing of fin has been shown effective over time because finasteride accumulates in your tissues with a half life of 28 days.

>b-bt-b-tb-tb-tb-tbut muh you could die!
Good I was suicidal anyway, if this is what takes me out then whatever, but science says it'll be fine. So far I find no adverse effects on this tiny dose.

The reason everyone takes 1mg is because that's what's prescribed, and that's what's prescribed because it's what was tested during the trials for prescription for hair loss. The data all shows that's basically overdosing on fin, it's no wonder people get side effects this way.

Hello /fit/.

I, a beginner, have chosen this to be my routine:

A:
DL 3x5
Bench 3x8
Pull-Ups 3x8
2-3 Accessories I feel like doing

B:
Squat 3x8
OHP 3x8
Row 3x8
2-3 Accessories I feel like doing

I'm doing this 3x a week and 1-2 times running if I can manage it on the other days.

I don't care if this plan isn't absolutely optimal, because I enjoy it and it keeps me going, which I think is more important than a perfect routine, but still I want to know if there is something that is wrong with it or that you'd change.
Also, how long can I stay on this plan? Meaning, how "big" can I get with this until I no longer progress? Will I be able look good (by normie standards, not /fit/ standards) by just doing this routine or will I have to switch to a split someday?

Thanks and have a nice weekend, friend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69586680
>hands
Got nothing, sorry. All you can do is gain weight and/or spend an absurd amount of time doing movements that will thicken up all the tendons in the hand like rockclimbers, but this won't make your hand larger, just thicker (Though gaining weight and by extension fat might make them very slightly longer/wider, it won't be that much)
>wrist
Over time the tendons can thicken up from use, if you progress on forearm exercises that heavily use the tendons while making sure you don't get tendonitis this could probably speed it up. Maybe look into pinch gripping multiple plates or something 6-10 cm wide as I find that you tend to feel the tendons in your wrist a LOT when pinch gripping stuff with a more open hand. Also axle bars/fat grips tend to also use the tendons more so you can try that too. This would be a very long process but it is doable. Other than that just get big and strong overall.
>forearms
The three main parts that will contribute the most to size are:
>flexors
Finger curls, wrist roller
>extensors
Wrist extensions, reverse wrist roller
>brachioradialis
EZ bar reverse curls, don't use a thumbless grip as your grip will give out. Don't cheat at all with your hips/back, use a slow eccentric, and don't raise your elbows, and use wrist wraps. Otherwise you may fuck up your wrists (happened to me, I learned my lesson, now I can do these with no issue). Hammer curls are also good but they won't bias the brachioradialis as much, they're more of a hybrid lift (however you can use fat grips on them without any problems so maybe do that)

Myoreps are also very good for finger curls and reverse/hammer curls so try that as well. Train forearms frequently as they recover fairly fast, and I highly recommend using supersets/giantsets whenever you can to save time as forearm exercises are not very taxing.
